(Same as REL 326 1)  This course will be taught online. It meets for one synchronous 75-minute session per week on Wednesdays. The rest of the material will be delivered asynchronously.
This course satisfies the new Religion major requirement:- Tradition-Christianity, Theme.  
This virtual course exposes students to a wide range of contexts, socio-cultural environments and global arrangements that have shaped diverse expressions of Black Christian thought primarily in North America but also in Africa and the wider African diaspora, especially since the Civil Rights and Black Power Movements.  Given our current moment of domestic and global upheaval regarding legacies of chattel slavery, colonial conquest, anti-Black and anti-Brown racism and their collateral consequences, we will place emphasis upon Black Christian nationalism, Black liberation theology, womanist theology, Afro-Caribbean & Afro-Latin American/Latinx popular religion and theology and African theology.  Although we will engage diverse scholarly approaches to Black Christian thought, the course emphasizes liberation theological inquiry, methods and rhetorical styles, and asks students to engage across the semester an activist or activist organization involved in the struggle against anti-Blackness and racial oppression in the United States.
course_description: Spiritual transformations involving worship, magic and healing, ritual, and aesthetic performance in Black speech and literature, music, and drama; and spiritual uses of Biblical themes to empower social political movements.
